comments.commentBody: Koob  - right about standard of living for average Chinese citizen.  I expect the Bay Bridge used Chinese steel though.  China goes big and we can't even muster $50 billion for improvements or even a lot of maintanance.  The Chinese have usually thought in centuries.  We battle over small tax increases even to maintain.  If climate change doesn't destroy us all I'm not sure who's going to come out on top at this point.  And coming out on top seems to be the only goal.  I'd still rather live here but we need to wake up.

The criticisms of this article has some valid points. But overall, a country of population size like China needs good infrastructure, and we (I'm Chinese) are not there yet. Many of the constructions listed in the article are related to public transportation and clean energy, which in the long run will improve living standards (e.g., faster travel between the cities/regions) and environment too (more subways and less driving)!
Investing money in domestic infrastructure (although it does not generate much revenue as the article points out) makes far more sense to me than lending the money to the riches country in the world.

I get your point but the same can be said of many other things.  Football, to me  is way more than just a bunch of guys banging into each other.  It is pride (school, state and conference), it is excitement, joy, partying, debate, etc.  It is also ridiculously dangerous but it is definitely not "only football."
N.C.G. or not, it's still only football.

There is an article in this paper today discussing the problem with teaching history in Virginia.  Heck, 47% of all Americans think that the world was created almost 5000 years after Chinese history started.  But what do I know?
Money doesn't fix all problems, but it certainly helps ease lots of pains when you have it.

"this is also the nation that is afraid to hear its citizens' voice, cannot tolerate opposite political viewpoints, and refuse to teach history truthfully."

Let me counter with the voters in Florida passing BY VOTE a high speed rail line TWICE that was thwarted by Republican Governors, the talking heads on TV that argue for sport about nothing except their own "ideas" of social norms, and the fact that many U.S. educators unfortunately believe that evolution is a farse, global warming is a plot, and we won a war in the middle east . . .

I applaud China's effort in taking the impressive measure to modernize. However, this is also the nation that is afraid to hear its citizens' voice, cannot tolerate opposite political viewpoints, and refuse to teach history truthfully. From a purely sociological observation, China is avoiding its political and social responsibilities by spending its way to impress the rest. Money doesn't fix all problems, and China still has a long way to grow.

my father was in his nineties when he broke his shoulder in a pedestrian/automobile interaction.  The doctors advised to do nothing. He had splinters of bone poking his skin for several years and pain--I regretted that we did not guide him thru surgery- he would have done whatever was recommended- having been a test pilot - he was unaffraid.  I regret that family did not urge him to do the surgery and everybody is an individual no matter what age..

Your father's injuries were quite awful and only surgery would have corrected the alignment of the bones.  Surgery is a huge risk for anyone in their nineties.  Sorry that he suffered the pain but I believe you would have lost him sooner than necessary.

Have to disagree with you there - logically surgery was the only way of improving/restoring his quality of life; the anticipated quantity of life vis a vis surgery would require more knowledge of his overall condition/comorbidities and "lost him sooner than necessary" is an entirely speculative construct on your part.

Once a person is 80 or 90 yrs old if they have serious health issues a DNR should be in effect for them.  Giving elderly patients statins is harmful.  Giving 90 yr old women Calcium can also be harmful.  Many treatment practices are still "old school" and presribing such medications and supplements should be discontinued as they are of little value and do nothing to improve the quality of life.

Once again in the wake of a tragedy that was most likely unpreventable, the governments of the west being telling their own people that the only way to protect them from future acts is to further curb their freedoms. Heaven forbid the governments do anything like changing their foreign policies or anything that would have an actual effect. When the extremists attack and the governments use it to further their own agendas, it's the public in the middle that always lose. As an expat in a country like China, I really see now how the freedoms like are lacking here that we laud ourselves for having in the west are very slowly chipped away. At least the Chinese government does it without the illusion of freedom or democracy and without using the tragic events of other countries to justify it's own ends.
With the current state of affairs in the land of GOP, it's more like "No Deal" rather than "New Deal."

It really sounds like they not only have a great transportation vision,but they are actualizing it to a reality..Perhaps we could use another 'New Deal' concept to put people to work on our massive transportation structure..and do it in a way that benefits 'The People' and not focus on the corporate profit motivation. That,in my opinion, makes wonderful sense,so it will probably never happen..
The last lines of this story reminds me of Arthur C. Clarke's short story "Rescue Party", in which is described a rail tunnel that runs from New York under the Atlantic to Europe.

I think that America and China have inverted takes on the scope of symbols; for the Chinese, high-magnitude defines national images, whereas in the US, large goes for individual status symbols like McMansions and Escalades.  But with every large-scale endeavor, China does send a message globally that momentum is with them.

Paul:

If you have time, you might enjoy reading "Fields of Blood: Religion and the History of Violence," by Karen Armstrong, for a more nuanced examination of the similarities and differences between Europe and the Middle East.

White supremacy, racism, and xenophobia enjoyed fertile ground in both imperial and settler-colonial societies for centuries before globalization resulted in human civilization becoming multicultural as a whole.

No one lives in an isolated place anymore, and every culture has dispersed everywhere. Old, local social hierarchies feel weak and artificial because they are; they could always only be enforced with violence.

Now everybody lives on the same planet, part of one human race. Some people find it painfully hard to give up the advantages bestowed on them by the status quo; others find the disadvantages it foist on them no longer possible to endure.

So the transition isn't easy, and there are political actors out there from religious extremists to right-wing ideologues who take advantage of instability to further their own ambitions.

But if there is one positive consequence of the intimacy we find has been thrust on us -- leaving aside the virtual destruction of the life support systems of the Earth -- it is that conscious understanding and mutual acceptance of each other is within reach.

But yes, by all means, congrats on the gargantua superfluous infrastructure projects. We will look on their works and despair, I reckon?

I think you identified the fundamental emotional problem, death is frightening and sad. The way we, as a society, have chosen to deal with that is to use the medical system as a scapegoat to exonerate ourselves from any responsibility for frightening or saddening a dying person. "We did everything we could" are the only words that are acceptable in connection with a death. Anything else is heard as an incrimination of moral failing.

This shabby case further illustrates the simple fact of the matter that Government, whose basic powers are enumerated in the seven Articles of the Constitution, can, from time to time, rise up to become the enemy of the People, whose inalienable rights are enumerated in the Bill of Rights. And that, but for those Amendments to the Constitution, the Government might eventually proclaim itself the lords and masters of the people.

I believe I read somewhere that Ms. Poitras and a colleague came to the U.S. to accept an award for Defending Free Press, or something like that; and during her transit through Customs and her stay in this country, Ms. Poitras was not hounded, harassed, or accosted (except to the extent that anyone is when they go through Customs or try to get somewhere from the airport in time for dinner).

I am obviously not researching, merely going from memory; so if I'm wrong, please tell me.

A relief,  but the government is still hounding Laura Poitras,  whose Citizenfour I heartily recommend to everyone.  Risen's sin was to expose a botched operation.  The government replied by wrapping its incompetence in the mantle of national security.  You get an idea of how much the Obama administration values freedom of the press by the absence of anyone from Washington at that incredible march in Paris.  Even Abbas and Netanyahu showed up.

It seems improbable that the CIA doesn't know exactly what is going on, especially given its relationship with the NSC, NSA, and the FBI.

What this really seems to be about is what has been the case since the Reagan years--intimidating the press, destroying journalists' means to reveal the workings of our ever-present secret government.

If the FBI--with a little help from their friends--can use fear via the Washington Post to destroy Nixon, why not use same to freeze the minds of any reporters searching for truth or of concerned government employees who deviate from the party line?

Fear always works its magic, even with a First Amendment standing guard--though in this case, Risen seems to have stood firm.
I disagree. Bush, Obama and Holder all knew it was wrong to begin with.

Let's keep a little perspective. Risen should not have been put in this position in the first place, let alone be left to dangle in the wind for seven years. And, yes, the harassment of him is a significant blot on the Bush and Obama Administrations.

That said, in how many countries in the world would someone who the government so clearly targeted get to walk away in the end? America is a work in progress. Let's not forget that fact.

I am delighted that the Atorney General did the right thing, at last.

But, what took him so long, and why did Justice insist on the Kabuki play testimony of Mr. Risen? Short answer, to establish a precedent so that a future Attorney General could decide at whim to shred the 1st Amendment, even though Holder didn't.

Still, the prosecution of Sterling is troubling. Let's assume, for the sake of argument that he took whistle blowing a step too far/ Not sure that he did, but let's say so. He still, is by any definition, a whistleblower.

In Henry Kissinger's wonderful definition, the Ship of State is the only ship that leaks at the top. Perhaps they will prosecute Petraeus, but not for talking to star reporters. If there is no benefit to the Republic in prosecuting former SECDEF Panetta (and I don't think there is) there is none in letting Justice engage in selective, harsh prosecution of an ordinary whistleblower.
